facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 376 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 5, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 545 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 376 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 5, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, in Second Appeal No. 545 of 1955.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on March 29, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 29. The judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-This appeal by special leave is directed against the decision of a learned single judge of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh in a second appeal preferred before it by the respondent.

facts.text: Survey No.440-B situated in Rakatla village originally belonged to one Boya Krishnappa and measured 166 acres.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to the present appeal are number many and they lie within a very narrow companypass. Survey No.440-B situated in Rakatla village originally belonged to one Boya Krishnappa and it measured 166 acres.

facts.text: Appellants' father Chinna Venkataramanappa purchased 40 acres out of Survey No.440-B from Boya Krishnappa about 35 years before the date of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the suit filed by the appellants in the Court of Subordinate Judge, Anantapur in 1951  0. S. No. 72 of 1953 , the appellants alleged that 40 acres out of the said land had been purchased by their father, Chinna Venkataramanappa from Boya Krishnappa about 35 years before the date of the suit for companysideration.

facts.text: After the sale, appellants' father obtained possession of the property and continued in possession during his lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: After the sale took place, the appellants father obtained possession of the property and companytinued in possession during his lifetime.

facts.text: On father's death, appellants' mother acting as guardian remained in possession and management until 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On his death, the appellants mother acting as their guardian remained in possession and management of the said property until 1947.

facts.text: Appellants' family paid the assessment for the land and was in open and peaceful possession until 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants family had been paying the assessment for the land all the time and had been in its possession in an open and peaceful manner until 1947.

facts.text: Respondent obtained a mortgage decree in O.S. No. 94/1940 against Boya Krishnappa in respect of entire Survey No.440-B.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent had obtained a mortgage decree in 0. S. No. 94/1940 against Boya Krishnappa in respect of the entire SurveyNo.440-B and in pursuance of the said mortgagedecree, brought the mortgaged property to sale.

facts.text: Respondent purchased the property at court sale in about 1943.

anchor.surface_text: At the companyrt sale, the respondent purchased the property himself in about 1943, and thereafter liebegan to obstruct the possession of the appellants.

facts.text: In 1947, respondent unlawfully entered upon the land in suit, dispossessing appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In 1947,the respondent managed to enter upon theland in suit unlawfully and that gave rise to the present suit.

facts.text: Boya Krishnappa executed mortgage deed in favour of respondent on July 31, 1929, including suit property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants pleaded that though Boya Krishnappa may have included the suit property in the mortgage deed executed by him in favour of the respondent on July 31, 1929, the said mortgage did number affect the appellants title -to the property which had already been purchased by their father from the said Krishnappa

facts.text: Suit filed by appellants in Court of Subordinate Judge, Anantapur as O.S. No. 72 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: in the Court of Subordinate Judge, Anantapur in 1951  0. S. No. 72 of 1953 , the appellants alleged that 40 acres out of the said land had been purchased by their father

facts.text: Respondent denied purchase by appellants' father and claimed appellants cultivated as tenants of Boya Krishnappa.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was resisted by the respondent. He denied that the appellants father had purchased the property from Krishnappa and that the assessment for the land had ever been paid by the appellants family as owners. According to him, the appellants had been cultivating the land in suit as tenants of Boya Krishnappa

facts.text: Trial court (Subordinate Judge) answered issues in favour of appellants, decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: Both these issues were answered by the trial judge in favour of the appellants. On the question about the appellants title, the trial judge placed the burden on the appellants

facts.text: District Judge affirmed trial court's decree in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged this decree by preferring an appeal in the Court of the District judge at Anantapur. The learned District judge framed one companyprehensive point for determination and that was whether the appellants had proved title to and possession of the suit property within 12 years before the date of their suit.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court single judge allowed respondent's second appeal, dismissed appellants' suit.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decree passed in his appeal by the District Court, the respondent moved the High Court under section 100 P. C., and his appear was heard by Sanjeeva Rao Nayudu J. ... allowed the second appeal preferred by the respondent and directed that the appellants suit should be dismissed with companyts throughout.

facts.text: Respondent admitted appellants' family possession of the land.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the respondent clearly admitted that the appellants family had been in possession of the land, but he explained the said possession on the allegation that they were the tenants of Boya Krishnappa.

facts.text: Lands including Survey No. 440-B were banjar about 20 or 25 years ago, of no value.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts have numbericed the fact that the respondent himself had admitted that about 20 or 25 years ago, all the lands in the locality including surevy No. 440-B were banjar, they were of numbervalue and people were getting them for the mere asking.

facts.text: Mortgage deed for 166 acres advanced Rs. 650 only.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the mortgage deed executed in favour of the respondent supports this admission. The mortgage was in regard to 166 acres and the amount advanced was Rs. 650/only.

facts.text: Appellants stood sureties for crops in execution proceedings of mortgage decree.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that when the respondent put the mortgaged properties to sale in execution of his mortgage decree against Krishnappa, a Commissioner was appointed to value the crops standing in the land and in those proceedings, the appellants stood sureties for the crops at the instance of Krishnappa.

facts.text: Trial court relied on Exhibit A-8 Changes Register showing appellants' father and then appellants as Pattadars.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit A-8 is certified companyy of the Changes Register of Rakatla village. This document showed the names of Boya Krishnappa and Venkataramanappa, the father of the appellants as the Pattadars. After the death of Venkataramanappa a circle was put round his name ... were registered as Pattadars.

facts.text: Cist receipts Exts. A-2 to A-5 and A-9 to A-35 showed payment by appellants' family.

anchor.surface_text: A number of cist receipts were produced by the appellants  Exts. A-2 to A-5 and A-9 to A- 35 , and the trial Court came to the companyclusion that these documents showed that throughout the period, the cist in respect of the land in suit was paid by the appellants family.

facts.text: High Court held Ext. A-8 not proved and doubtful, but conceded error in law.

anchor.surface_text: He was inclined to hold that Ext. A-8 had number been proved at all and companyld number, therefore, be receive  in evidence. It has been fairly companyceded by Mr. Sastri for the respondent before us that this was plainly erroneous in law.

arguments.claim: High Court interfered with concurrent findings of fact, contravening s.100 CPC limits in second appeal

arguments.court_reasoning: Sole ground for special leave and allowing appeal

arguments.claim: No jurisdiction in second appeal on erroneous findings of fact (citing Mussummat Durga Choudhrain)

anchor.surface_text: As early as 1890 in the case of Mussummat Durga Choudhrain v. Jawahir Singh Choudhri,  1 , the Privy Council emphatically declared that under s.584 of the earlier Code, which corresponds to s.100 of the present Code, there is no jurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of erroneous finding of fact,

arguments.claim: Sufficiency or adequacy of evidence is not a substantial question of law under s.100 CPC for second appeal

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 100, C. P. C., some learned judges of the High Courts are disposing of second appeals as if they were first appeals. ... sufficiency or adequacy of evidence to sustain a conclusion of fact is a matter of law

arguments.claim: Interfering with findings of fact in second appeals introduces gambling element and confusion

anchor.surface_text: This introduces, apart from the fact that the High Court assumes and exercises a jurisdiction which it does number possess, a gambling element in litigation and confusion in the mind of the litigant public.

arguments.claim: High Courts must follow caution in Durga Choudhrain and not treat second appeals as first appeals (citing Deity Pattabhiramaswami, Ramachandra Ayyar)

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Deity Pattabhiramaswamiv. S. Hanymayya  2 , this Court had occasion to refer to the said decision of the Privy Council and it was constrained to observe that notwithstanding such clear and authoritative pronouncements on the scope of the provisions of s. 100, C. P. C.,

holdings.text: The High Court contravened the provisions of section 100 CPC by interfering with concurrent findings of fact recorded by the courts below in allowing the second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It is the validity of this decree which is challenged before us by the appellants and the principal ground on which the challenge rests is that in reversing concurrent findings of fact recorded by the courts below, the learned judge has clearly contravened the provisions of s. 100 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court re-examined genuineness and sufficiency of documentary evidence (Ext. A-8, cist receipts) and conduct, setting aside concurrent findings, which is beyond s.100 scope citing Durga Choudhrain.

holdings.text: Certified copy of a public document like Ext. A-8 need not be proved by calling a witness, especially when no objection was raised to mode of proof.

anchor.surface_text: It has been fairly conceded by Mr. Sastri for the respondent before us that this was plainly erroneous in law. The document in question being a certified copy of a public document need not have been proved by calling a witness. Besides, no objection had been raised about the mode of proof

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding Ext. A-8 unproved; Evidence Act permits certified public documents without formal proof, conceded by counsel.

holdings.text: The appellants proved possessory title to the suit property by open, continuous and adverse possession for more than the statutory period until 1947, which was within 12 years of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The possession of the land was admitted to be with the appellants family for more than the statutory period and as such, it was open and continuous. The plea of the respondent that the said possession was that of a tenant was rejected, and so, the said possession in law was adverse against the whole world. It was also clear that the possession continued until 1947 which was within twelve years before the date of the suit,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings based on documentary evidence (Changes Register, cist receipts), admitted possession not explained as tenancy, within limitation period under Art. 64 Limitation Act.

holdings.text: A registered document was not necessary to convey title to the appellants' father given the low value of banjar land (mortgage Rs.650 for 166 acres).

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts have noticed the fact that the respondent himself had admitted that about 20 or 25 years ago, all the lands in the locality including survey No. 440-B were banjar, they were of no value and people were getting them for the mere asking. In fact, the mortgage deed executed in favour of the respondent supports this admission. The mortgage was in regard to 166 acres and the amount advanced was Rs. 650/- only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Land value below Rs.100 exempt under Registration Act s.17(2)(v); absence of registered deed not fatal to title claim, supplemented by possession evidence.

holdings.text: The court sale in execution of mortgage decree was not binding on the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Since it found that the property belonged to the appellants family either by transfer or by reason of adverse possession, it held that the mortgage executed by Krishnappa in favour of the respondent and subsequent proceedings under the said mortgage did not affect the appellants title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior purchase or adverse possession predated mortgage; lower courts' findings upheld.

holdings.text: Sufficiency or adequacy of evidence to sustain findings of fact cannot be agitated in second appeal under s.100 CPC; it is for courts of fact.

anchor.surface_text: It has been always recognised that the sufficiency or adequacy of evidence to support a finding of fact is a matter for decision of the court of facts and cannot be agitated in a second appeal. Sometimes, this position is expressed by saying that like all questions of fact, sufficiency or adequacy of evidence in support of a case is also left to the jury for its verdict.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's view misconceived; precedents (Durga Choudhrain, Pattabhiramaswami, Ramachandra Ayyar) affirm s.100 limits to substantial questions of law, not evidence appreciation.

holdings.text: Supreme Court must intervene under Art.136 when High Court contravenes s.100 CPC limits in second appeals.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, whenever this Court is satisfied that in dealing with a second appeal, the High Court has, either unwittingly and in a casual manner, or deliberately as in this case, contravened the limits prescribed by s. 100, it becomes the duty of this Court to intervene and give effect to the said provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Duty to enforce statutory limits; prevents unpredictability and gambling in litigation.

precedents.citation: Mussummat Durga Choudhrain v. Jawahir Singh Choudhri,  1

anchor.surface_text: Mussummat Durga Choudhrain v. Jawahir Singh Choudhri,  1 , the Privy Council emphatically declared that under s.584 of the earlier Code, which corresponds to s.100 of the present Code, there is nojurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of erroneous finding of fact, however gross or inexcusable the error may seem to be and they added a number of warning that noCourt in India has power to add to, or enlarge, the grounds specified in s.100.

precedents.case_name: Mussummat Durga Choudhrain v. Jawahir Singh Choudhri
precedents.cited_proposition: under s.584 of the earlier Code, which corresponds to s.100 of the present Code, there is no jurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of erroneous finding of fact, however gross or inexcusable the error may seem to be and no Court in India has power to add to, or enlarge, the grounds specified in s.100

anchor.surface_text: Mst. Durga Choudhrain  1 . In the case of Deity Pattabhiramaswamiv. S. Hanymayya  2 , this Court had occasion to refer to the said decision of the Privy Council and it was constrained to observe that notwithstanding such clear and authoritative pronouncements on the scope of the provisions of s. 100, C. P. C., some learned.judges of the High Courts are disposing of second appeals as if they were first appeals.

precedents.cited_proposition: earliest pronouncement of the Privy Council on limits of powers in second appeals under s.100 CPC

anchor.surface_text: Deity Pattabhiramaswamiv. S. Hanymayya  2 , this Court had occasion to refer to the said decision of the Privy Council and it was constrained to observe that notwithstanding such clear and authoritative pronouncements on the scope of the provisions of s. 100, C. P. C., some learned.judges of the High Courts are disposing of second appeals as if they were first appeals. This introduces, apart from the fact that the High Court assumes and exercises a jurisdiction which it does not possess, a gambling element in litigation and confusion in the mind of the litigant public.

precedents.cited_proposition: notwithstanding clear pronouncements on scope of s.100 CPC, some High Court judges dispose of second appeals as first appeals, introducing gambling element

precedents.citation: R. Ramachandra Ayyar v. Ramalingam Chettiar  3

anchor.surface_text: R. Ramachandra Ayyar v. Ramalingam Chettiar  3 , this Court had occasion to revert to the same subject once again. The true legal position in regard to the powers of the second appellate Court under s. 100 was once more examined and it was pointed out that the learned judges of the High Courts should bear in mind the caution and warning pronounced by the Privy Council in the case of Mst. Durga Chowdhrain 1  and should not interfere with findings of fact.

precedents.case_name: R. Ramachandra Ayyar v. Ramalingam Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: powers of second appellate court under s.100 CPC; High Courts should bear in mind caution from Durga Choudhrain and not interfere with findings of fact

anchor.surface_text: Mst. Durga Chowdhrain 1  and should not interfere with findings of fact. It appears that the decision of this Court in Deity Pattabhiramaswamy  2 , was in fact cited before the learned single judge, but he was inclined to take the view that some aspects of the provisions contained in s. 100 of the Code had not been duly considered by this Court and so, he thought that it was open to him to interfere with the conclusions of the courts below in the present appeal.

precedents.cited_proposition: caution and warning pronounced by the Privy Council that courts should not interfere with findings of fact in second appeals

anchor.surface_text: Deity Pattabhiramaswamy  2 , was in fact cited before the learned single judge, but he was inclined to take the view that some aspects of the provisions contained in s. 100 of the Code had not been duly considered by this Court and so, he thought that it was open to him to interfere with the conclusions of the courts below in the present appeal. According to the learned judge, it is open to the second appellate Court to interfere with the conclusions of fact recorded by the District judge not only where the said conclusions are based on noevidence, but also where the said conclusions are based on evidence which the High Court considers insufficient to support them.

precedents.cited_proposition: decision cited before the High Court judge but he thought some aspects of s.100 not considered

anchor.surface_text: It is the validity of this decree which is challenged before us by the appellants and the principal ground on which the challenge rests is that in reversing concurrent findings of fact recorded by the courts below, the learned judge has clearly contravened the provisions of s. 100 of the Code.
That is the sole ground on which leave has been granted to the appellants and on which we propose to allow this appeal.
That is the sole ground on which leave has been granted to the appellants and on which we propose to allow this appeal.
y the trial Court was number prepared to attach any significance to this circumstances Since it found that the property belonged to the appellants fam

edges.explanation: Holding finds possession until 1947 within 12 years, supporting application of limitation concept

anchor.surface_text: The possession of the land was admitted to be with the appellants family for more than the statutory period and as such, it was open and continuous. The plea of the respondent that the said possession was that of a tenant was rejected, and so, the said possession in law was adverse against the whole world. It was also clear that the possession continued until 1947 which was within twelve years before the date of the suit,
That is the sole ground on which leave has been granted to the appellants and on which we propose to allow this appeal.
to give security for the said crops when the mortgagor Krishnappa was directed to furnish security for the value of the crops on the lands companyered

edges.explanation: Holding h4 that registered document not necessary given low value directly addresses issue i4 of whether registered document necessary to convey title to appellants' father.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts have noticed the fact that the respondent himself had admitted that about 20 or 25 years ago, all the lands in the locality including survey No. 440-B were banjar, they were of no value and people were getting them for the mere asking. In fact, the mortgage deed executed in favour of the respondent supports this admission. The mortgage was in regard to 166 acres and the amount advanced was Rs. 650/- only.
That is the sole ground on which leave has been granted to the appellants and on which we propose to allow this appeal.

Since it found that the property belonged to the appellants family either by transfer or by reason of adverse possession, it held that the mortgage executed by Krishnappa in favour of the respondent and subsequent proceedings under the said mortgage did not affect the appellants title.
That is the sole ground on which leave has been granted to the appellants and on which we propose to allow this appeal.
he earliest pronouncements of the Privy Council on this point is to be found in the case of Mst. Durga Choudhrain  1 . In the case of Deity Pattabhira

edges.explanation: Holding h6 that sufficiency cannot be agitated under s.100 CPC addresses issue i6 on whether it is a matter of law.

anchor.surface_text: It has been always recognised that the sufficiency or adequacy of evidence to support a finding of fact is a matter for decision of the court of facts and cannot be agitated in a second appeal. Sometimes, this position is expressed by saying that like all questions of fact, sufficiency or adequacy of evidence in support of a case is also left to the jury for its verdict.
That is the sole ground on which leave has been granted to the appellants and on which we propose to allow this appeal.

edges.explanation: Holding on Art.136 intervention grounds application of CONST_ART136

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, whenever this Court is satisfied that in dealing with a second appeal, the High Court has, either unwittingly and in a casual manner, or deliberately as in this case, contravened the limits prescribed by s. 100, it becomes the duty of this Court to intervene and give effect to the said provisions.
That is the sole ground on which leave has been granted to the appellants and on which we propose to allow this appeal.
